case_title: JAYALAKSHMI CLOTH STORES vs INCOME TAX OFFICER, GUDIVADA AND OTHERS
complaint_summary: The petitioner challenged the rejection of appeals by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal on grounds of limitation, arguing that the appellate orders were improperly served on an erstwhile partner of the dissolved firm instead of the managing partner or authorized representative.
investigation_summary: The appellate orders were served on Sri A. Subba Rao, an erstwhile partner of the dissolved firm, contrary to the address provided in Form No. 35 by the managing partner. This led to a delay in filing appeals before the Tribunal.
judgment_summary: The court held that the service of appellate orders on Sri A. Subba Rao was improper and contrary to law. It quashed the Tribunal's orders rejecting the appeals as time-barred and directed the Tribunal to accept the appeals as filed within the limitation period.
Decision_or_verdict: Order quashed; Tribunal directed to accept appeals.
legal_arguments: Service of appellate orders must follow the address provided in Form No. 35 under Rule 45 of the Income-tax Rules, 1962.
Section 283(2) of the Income-tax Act does not apply to appellate proceedings.
Rules of natural justice require proper service of appellate orders to the appellant or authorized representative.
citations: K. D. Kalra & Co. v. CTT [1975] Tax LR 614
key_issues: Applicability of Section 283(2) to appellate proceedings

maxims.Natural Justice: Proper service of orders is essential to ensure fairness.

legal_terms.Appellant: The party who files an appeal.

words_and_phrases.Barred by Limitation: Appeals filed beyond the prescribed time limit.
words_and_phrases.Dissolved Firm: A partnership firm that has ceased to exist.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around procedural irregularities in the service of appellate orders, leading to a delay in filing appeals. The court emphasized adherence to statutory rules and principles of natural justice, quashing the Tribunal's rejection of appeals as time-barred.

facts.address_specified: Managing partner or authorised representative, Sri Ramamohana Rao, Advocate, Gudivada
facts.order_served_on: Sri A. Subba Rao, an erstwhile partner of the dissolved firm

arguments.petitioner: AAC has a statutory duty to serve appellate orders on the appellant or authorised representative as specified in Form No. 35.
arguments.respondent: Service on one of the partners of the dissolved firm is valid under Section 283(2) of the Income Tax Act.

court_findings.form_requirement: Form No. 35 requires the appellant to specify the address for service of notices and orders.
court_findings.service_error: AAC served the order on an erstwhile partner who did not file the appeal or take interest in the matter.
court_findings.limitation_period: Sixty days for filing appeals starts from the date of knowledge of the order by the appellant.

court_decision.direction: Tribunal to receive memoranda of appeals filed by the petitioner.
